title: Neighbours fear 'rowdy' stag and hen parties will flock to the world's first vagina museum in London
text:
Florence Schechter, the director of the world's first vagina museum

A London museum dedicated to vaginas has been granted an alcohol licence, with neighbours fearing it could attract 'rowdy' stag and hen parties.

The Vagina Museum is due to open on November 16 in Camden Market, London, with the aim of spreading knowledge about 'gynaecological anatomy and health'.

According to its website it is the 'world's first bricks and mortar museum dedicated to vaginas'.

The museum has received widespread support with the public raising almost £50,000 to fund it and the Camden Council leader saying she is 'incredibly excited' for it.

However, its application for an alcohol licence has sparked concern from local residents' groups.

Patricia Thomas, who wrote to Camden Council on behalf of the Harmood, Clarence, Hartland Residents Association, said the group was 'particularly alarmed' by the idea of hen and stag parties visiting the museum.

She said: 'We have no doubt that the museum will try to ensure that no inappropriate parties will be allowed, but stag parties are not known for their respectfulness and hen parties can also be raucous and difficult to control.

'If parties become rowdy, they will be removed by security and then end up on our streets, creating public nuisance.'

Kathryn Gemmell, chairman of Tenants Residents Associations, Camden Town, added the group was concerned that the museum was 'actively seeking' hen and stag nights.

Despite the concerns, the local authority's licensing panel granted the museum its alcohol licence on Thursday.

In a statement, museum director Florence Schechter said she was 'honoured' by the decision.

She added: 'At the hearing we heard and engaged with residents' concerns.'

Vagina Museum volunteer Jasmine Evans (left) and museum director Florence Schechter, who said they had 'heard and engaged with residents' concerns'

The museum had initially sought permission to supply alcohol between 10am and 11.30pm Monday to Thursday and Sunday, and from 10am to midnight on Fridays and Saturdays.

But it amended its application ahead of the meeting to supply alcohol between 6pm and 10.30pm Monday to Sunday, a Camden Council spokesperson said.

It was also granted a licence to show films between 10am and 10.30pm Monday to Saturday and 11am to 10.30pm on Sundays.

The licencing panel added a condition that no more than 100 people can be admitted into the museum at any one time, the council spokesperson said.

The museum's opening exhibition, entitled Muff Busters: Vagina Myths And How To Fight Them, begins on November 16.

It will host exhibitions that will change every six months and they will be on topics ranging from the history of period products, the science of animal vaginas and vulva art.

The Vagina Museum is due to open on November 16 in Camden Market, London

The museum will also hold performances, talks, plays, concerts and comedy shows, as well as workshops for making magazines, embroidery, protest signs, and more.

It will have its own dedicated shop where you can pick up merchandise, feminist books and jewellery.

The building also has a balcony and the museum will be hanging up Sheela Na Gigs and other vulva related bits of our history.

Sheela na gigs are carvings of naked women displaying an exaggerated vulva .

The museum will even host plants that have historically been used as period pain relief and contraception.

Councillor Georgia Gould, Leader of Camden Council, previously said: 'Camden has a proud and radical history of challenging prejudice and orthodoxy, however, we acknowledge that the stigma associated with talking about gynaecological health has meant ignorance, confusion, shame, and poor medical care for too many.

'65 per cent of 16-to-25 year olds say they have a problem using the word vagina or vulva with almost half of 18-to-24 year old women say they are too embarrassed to talk about sexual health issues.

'We are therefore incredibly excited that the Vagina Museum is seeking to establish in Camden, and hope that it is funded to provide an inclusive and intersectional centre for learning, creativity, activism, and outreach that will add immeasurably to our collective understanding of our bodies.'
description: The Vagina Museum is due to open on November 16 in Camden Market, London, with the aim of spreading knowledge about 'gynaecological anatomy and health'.
